Top-3 Scripts:
so_31691622: find . -type f -mtime -7 -exec mv {} newfolder \;

find . -type f -name *.log -mtime -7 -exec mv {} newfolder \;

-type f == meaning the pick all files only
-name *.log == having name like .log
-mtime -7== modified within 7 days
-exec == execute also on output from find meaning files found in find command
mv {} newfolder == move all the file found to newfolder
so_25740252: for a in $(find path/to/files -maxdepth 1 -type d); do mv $a/remove/* $a/; rmdir $a/remove; done

Explanations about Options.-name:
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.
Explanations about Options.-mtime:
File's data was last modified n*24 hours ago. See the comments for -atime to
 understand how rounding affects the interpretation of file modification times.

au_1243972: #!/bin/bash

for dir in *'(1)'*; do
    mv "$dir"/* "${dir% (1)}"
    rmdir "$dir"
done

Explanations about Options.-n: do not overwrite an existing file
